results.title: Lon Chaney: The Hunchback of Notre Dame
results.creator_credit: Saul J. Turell, Paul Killiam and Sterling Educational Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “History of the Motion Picture”.
A condensed version of the classic silent film of the Victor Hugo novel which was a masterpiece of film-making. Shows details of Lon Chaney’s elaborate makeup for his role as the hunchback Quasimodo and ends with an epilogue in tribute to the remarkable star. Dubbed “The man of a thousand faces”, Chaney’s portrayal of Quasimodo is not the only outstanding feature of this production. The set which took a year to build, the enormous cast of extras and night photography adds to the epic grandeur of the film which also starred Brandon Hurst, Nigel De Brulier and Patsy Ruth Miller as Esmeralda.
results.title_for_label: Lon Chaney: The Hunchback of Notre Dame
results.creator_credit_for_label: Saul J. Turell, Paul Killiam and Sterling Educational Films

The set which took a year to build, the enormous cast of extras and night photography adds to the epic grandeur of the film which also starred Brandon Hurst, Nigel De Brulier and Patsy Ruth Miller as Esmeralda.

results.title: The Story of the serials
results.creator_credit: Saul J. Turell, Paul Killiam and Sterling Educational Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “History of the Motion Picture”.
Excerpts from famous silent serials - including “The Perils of Pauline” and even earlier productions - succeed in recapturing the atmosphere of those early thrillers. Narrated by Paul Killiam.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Saul J. Turell, Paul Killiam and Sterling Educational Films

results.title: The Son of the Sheik. - [Edited version]
results.creator_credit: Saul J. Turell, Paul Killiam and Gregstan Enterprises
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “History of the Motion Picture”.
Presents an edited version of the 1926 production of “The Son of the Sheik”, a typical adventure of the golden age of the movies. Stars Rudolph Valentino. Narrated by Paul Killiam.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Saul J. Turell, Paul Killiam and Gregstan Enterprises

results.title: The Black pirate. - [Edited version]
results.creator_credit: Saul J. Turell, Paul Killiam and Gregstan Enterprises
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “History of the Motion Picture”.
An edited and narrated presentation of the duels, sea battles and acrobatics in the ‘Black Pirate’ an adventure film made in 1926 starring Douglas Fairbanks. Includes the famous sliding-down-the-sail stunt. Also stars Billie Dove.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Saul J. Turell, Paul Killiam and Gregstan Enterprises
results.description:

results.title: Intolerance: the fall of Babylon. - [Edited version]
results.creator_credit: Saul J. Turell, Paul Killiam and Sterling Educational Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “History of the Motion Picture”.
Still acknowledged as the biggest `spectacular’ of all, this section of the D.W. Griffith production has enormous full-scale sets of old Babylon, fantastic battle scenes, thousands of extras, and amazingly realistic reconstructions of the life, habits and customs of those ancient times. Includes Constance Talmadge, Seena Owen, Elmo Lincoln, Alfred Paget, Elmer Clinton and Wallace Reid.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Saul J. Turell, Paul Killiam and Sterling Educational Films

results.title: Nosferatu (Dracula). - [Edited version]
results.creator_credit: Saul J. Turell, Paul Killiam and Sterling Educational Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “History of the Motion Picture”.
A horror tale about a vampire who stalks his victims in the deepening shadows of the night. An edited version of the 1922 German silent motion picture, Nosferatu (Dracula), directed by F. W. Murnau, with commentary. Cast features Max Schreck as Dracula.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Saul J. Turell, Paul Killiam and Sterling Educational Films
results.description:

results.title: Yankee clipper. - [Edited version]
results.creator_credit: Cecil B. DeMille, Saul J. Turell, Paul Killiam and Sterling Educational Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “History of the Motion Picture”.
William Boyd, a popular star even in those days before his portrayal of Hopalong Cassidy, is seen in a condensed version of the 1927 adventure romance film produced by Cecil B. De Mille. Boyd stars as the captain of an American clipper that outruns the British to win the China tea trade.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Cecil B. DeMille, Saul J. Turell, Paul Killiam and Sterling Educational Films

results.title: Variety. - [Edited version]
results.creator_credit: Saul J. Turell, Paul Killiam and Sterling Educational Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “History of the Motion Picture”.
An edited version for the History of the Motion Picture series of the German film “Variety” produced by Ufa and directed by E.A. Dupont in 1925. The revolutionary photographic techniques of this important and influential German film had a profound effect on filmmaking everywhere. A strong stark drama of human passions set against a circus and vaudeville background. It is generally considered to be the best film of both its star, Emil Jannings, and its director, E.A. Dupont. Silent film with music and story line narration added.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Saul J. Turell, Paul Killiam and Sterling Educational Films

Silent film with music and story line narration added.

results.title: The Three musketeers. - [Edited version]
results.creator_credit: Saul J. Turell, Paul Killiam and Sterling Educational Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “History of the Motion Picture”
An edited version of the 1921 silent film version of the Dumas novel starring Douglas Fairbanks in the role of D’Artagnan, with added commentary. A cloak-and-dagger adventure romance with sequences of lively duels, chases and acrobatics, and the drama of court intrigue, illustrating the silent action film at its best, adaptation of a popular novel to the screen, and the work of Fairbanks.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Saul J. Turell, Paul Killiam and Sterling Educational Films
